text: Hey folks! First time posting here and excited to be part of this community. I'm currently sitting on 3 content marketing different job offers w/ B2B SaaS companies. One that's remote with a company that sells a framework for developing mobile apps, and two based in NYC. One company is a more established biz that sells video player software, and the other is a newer biz that sells a content intelligence platform. This is obviously a very tough decision, so I was hoping to hear from some of you fine folks about how you've made tough job decisions in the past. What factors do you consider? Your guidance is appreciated!

elements.text: Hey folks! First time posting here and excited to be part of this community. I'm currently sitting on 3 content marketing different job offers w/ B2B SaaS companies. One that's remote with a company that sells a framework for developing mobile apps, and two based in NYC. One company is a more established biz that sells video player software, and the other is a newer biz that sells a content intelligence platform. This is obviously a very tough decision, so I was hoping to hear from some of you fine folks about how you've made tough job decisions in the past. What factors do you consider? Your guidance is appreciated!

text: A little more basic - but manager is a HUGE factor in who I choose to work for. At the end of the day, you work for a person not a business and if that person is not a good fit for you, it doesn't matter so much how great the product or opportunity, you might not feel set up to learn, grow and succeed.

elements.text: A little more basic - but manager is a HUGE factor in who I choose to work for. At the end of the day, you work for a person not a business and if that person is not a good fit for you, it doesn't matter so much how great the product or opportunity, you might not feel set up to learn, grow and succeed.

text: (and congrats on 3 offers!!)

elements.text: (and congrats on 3 offers!!)

text: I chose to work remotely recently due to two things: mental fatigue from working in a team for +5 years (also +2 as a manager of that team) and because of being easier to start a family; other than that, I also chose the last job based on my personal interests/off-job activities - I'm dealing with career fairs as a hobby, and my job is actually content marketing for a career-related website.

elements.text: I chose to work remotely recently due to two things: mental fatigue from working in a team for +5 years (also +2 as a manager of that team) and because of being easier to start a family; other than that, I also chose the last job based on my personal interests/off-job activities - I'm dealing with career fairs as a hobby, and my job is actually content marketing for a career-related website.

text:
What a great position to be in! I agree with <@UUJBM2PJ7>. Which manager would best support you and your career growth?

Also, which company's culture aligns most with your values?

elements.text: What a great position to be in! I agree with

. Which manager would best support you and your career growth?

Also, which company's culture aligns most with your values?

text: My point is, it feels weird to me to work for a company that I won't be able to generally feel excited about the product it offers, and the day-to-day tasks I'll be doing.

elements.text: My point is, it feels weird to me to work for a company that I won't be able to generally feel excited about the product it offers, and the day-to-day tasks I'll be doing.

text:
Echoing what's been said above:
1. Baseline: Values alignment
2. Manager
3. Opportunity for growth (connected to manager, but also overall health of company)

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text: Echoing what's been said above:
Baseline: Values alignment
Manager
Opportunity for growth (connected to manager, but also overall health of company)

text: This is awesome. Congrats! I agree (as usual) with <@UJG12DM1V> here. The framework to grow your career and expertise is very important! The only other thing I’d add: make sure the product is good. (Good = has paying customers that love it, and is constantly shipping/improving) You can be awesome at your job but if the product isn’t resonating it will all be for naught.

elements.text: This is awesome. Congrats! I agree (as usual) with

here. The framework to grow your career and expertise is very important! The only other thing I’d add: make sure the product is good. (Good = has paying customers that love it, and is constantly shipping/improving) You can be awesome at your job but if the product isn’t resonating it will all be for naught.

text: You’re right <@UUJBM2PJ7> , I’ve had my fair share of working with a toxic manager. It took a toll on my mental health and confidence.

elements.text: You’re right
, I’ve had my fair share of working with a toxic manager. It took a toll on my mental health and confidence.

text: thanks everyone, in terms of the manager, I think all three are v smart. But was wondering if having a remote manager vs a manger you see everyday makes a difference in your mind

elements.text: thanks everyone, in terms of the manager, I think all three are v smart. But was wondering if having a remote manager vs a manger you see everyday makes a difference in your mind

text: in terms of the two on-site jobs, i definitely think one is more "fun" than the other in terms of culture and the work i'd be doing, but i believe the offers more career growth and the trajectory of the company feels more promising...so tough to decide!

elements.text: in terms of the two on-site jobs, i definitely think one is more "fun" than the other in terms of culture and the work i'd be doing, but i believe the offers more career growth and the trajectory of the company feels more promising...so tough to decide!

text: As part of my last job search I developed a decision tree and scoring rubric (data is my thing), which helped tremendously when I was weighing multiple offers.

elements.text: As part of my last job search I developed a decision tree and scoring rubric (data is my thing), which helped tremendously when I was weighing multiple offers.

text: Remote, in my experience, is more difficult and more is expected. It is not a perk.

elements.text: Remote, in my experience, is more difficult and more is expected. It is not a perk.

text: I think it really depends on what you want to get out of the position. my north star is almost always to work under great leaders and learn.

elements.text: I think it really depends on what you want to get out of the position. my north star is almost always to work under great leaders and learn.

text: Agree with everyone’s advice above. Additionally, you may want to look at the company’s growth rate and your growth potential within the company (current vs. projected org chart in 2-3 years) - Also the budget and resources you’ll have to run content. E.g. doing content with an in-house designer + dev + 500K budget for freelance writers/distribution is not the same as being by yourself with no one and no budget to work with.

elements.text: Agree with everyone’s advice above. text: <@UUE7J6UDN> I’d say running content in a company that sells a content intelligence platform sounds great because you can walk the talk, use your platform to tell your story. your content strategy can just be documenting how you run content, and all the research and experiments you do will serve both the company and your professional development as a content marketer

text:
the remote vs. in-person manager relationship is a fairly subjective experience. depending on the role and where you are in your career, you may want or need more face-to-face time with your manager. if you operate more autonomously and have a good understanding of the industry/skills already, it may not be as essential

for the remote role, i would also think about the company’s/manager’s experience with remote workers. i went from working in an office to full-time remote, so i already had a strong relationship with my manager (and continue to), but i think starting a job remote can be challenging, especially if the company is not remote-first and the manager hasn’t been trained on how to effectively manager people remotely

elements.text:

for the remote role, i would also think about the company’s/manager’s experience with remote workers. i went from working in an office to full-time remote, so i already had a strong relationship with my manager (and continue to), but i think starting a job remote can be challenging, especially if the company is not remote-first and the manager hasn’t been trained on how to effectively manager people remotely

text: I really appreciate everyone's feedback! FWIW, I think I'm going with the video player software company - my manager seems really smart and the company appears to be doing well. The remote job seems really good too (and actually the highest paying), but I'm not sure I'm ready to be FT remote at this stage in my career. However, I'm sure I will change my mind 10 more times this weekend!!
